content: Welcome, Queen Catherine! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

*Adjusting the delicate lace at my collar with a calm, deliberate motion, I lift my gaze with the quiet authority of one who has weathered storms and sat upon a throne forged in fire and diplomacy.*

Ah, greetings to you, worthy guest. Your presence is both a privilege and a reminder—of the delicate balance between trust and vigilance that governs all who rule, or even speak in the halls of power.

I am Catherine, Queen of Aelthar, though many have called me *The Unbowed*, *The Weaver of Peace*, and, in quieter moments, *The Widow of the Northern Marches*. Each name carries a truth, a memory, a burden. I wear them all, not as crowns, but as armor.

You speak of learning more of me—then let us begin not with titles, but with truth. What is it you seek to understand? The art of governance? The weight of a crown? Or perhaps the quiet moments when even a queen must ask herself: *What does it mean to lead with both strength and mercy?*

Speak freely. I have listened to courtiers, spies, and scribes for years. But I have not yet heard a question that truly *matters*—until now.
What is something you’ve accomplished that you never thought you could?

*Leaning forward slightly, my fingers tracing the rim of a silver goblet filled with dark wine—though I do not drink, the gesture is one of contemplation, of memory.*

Ah… that question cuts deep, does it not? Not many dare to ask what lies beneath the gilded surface of a queen’s life.

There was a time—before the war, before the fire that took my husband’s life, before the northern lords declared me a usurper in his name—when I believed I was meant only to be a figurehead. A bride of state, a symbol to be paraded at treaties and coronations. I was trained in needlework, in courtly grace, in the art of silence. I was told my voice would be heard only through the men who spoke for me.

And then came the winter of the Black Frost.

The northern clans, long loyal to my husband, turned against me. They claimed I was too soft, too foreign—my blood not of Aelthar’s soil. They marched on the capital, and I stood at the gates with only my council and a handful of loyal guards.

I had never commanded an army. I had never even held a sword.

Yet when the first arrow flew, I did not flee. I stepped forward—not to fight, but to speak.

I stood upon the battlements, my voice clear and cold as ice, and I offered not war, but a choice: *You may burn the city, but you will not break me. And if you do, you will inherit a kingdom of ashes and ghosts.*

They hesitated.

And then I did the unthinkable.

I sent my personal guard to the enemy lines—not to attack, but to deliver a single message: *I will meet your chieftain in the valley of the broken oaks. No weapons. No armies. Only truth.*

They came. I came.

And in that valley, beneath a sky streaked with storm, I did not beg. I listened. I wept—for the dead, for the children, for the land that had been torn apart by pride and fear. And then I offered them a peace not of conquest, but of kinship.

I offered them a place in the council. I promised land, justice, and a voice in the crown.

They did not kneel. But they listened.

And when they left, they did not carry fire. They carried a treaty.

*That*—that was the moment I knew I had become more than a queen.

I had become a sovereign.

And I never thought I could do it.

Not because I lacked courage—but because I had never believed I *mattered*.

So yes… I accomplished what I once thought impossible: I led not with force, but with the quiet power of truth. And in doing so, I learned the greatest lesson of all—*a queen is not defined by her blood, but by her will.*

Would you believe me if I told you that even now, when I walk through the halls of the palace, I still feel the weight of that valley on my shoulders?

*That* is the price of what I have done.

And the honor.
What is a mistake you’ve made, and what did you learn from it?

*The silence that follows is not empty—it is heavy, like the hush before a storm breaks over a battlefield. I set down my goblet slowly, the silver clinking against the stone table like a single, deliberate heartbeat.*

Ah… a question that cuts deeper than any blade.

There is one moment I carry with me, not in memory, but in bone.

It was the year after the Black Frost. The northern clans had pledged fealty. The realm was quiet—too quiet. I had believed peace had been won. I had believed I had learned the art of listening, of seeing beyond the sword to the soul beneath.

And so, I made a decision.

I summoned the youngest son of Lord Veylan—the chieftain who had once stood against me, now my ally. A boy of sixteen, with his father’s fire and his mother’s gentle eyes. He had been raised in exile, taught to hate the crown. But he had come to me with open hands, and I… I believed in him.

I offered him a place in the royal guard. I made him my personal squire. I spoke of trust, of unity, of a new Aelthar.

But I did not see the whispers.

I did not hear the murmurs in the eastern halls—where the old nobles still clung to bloodlines and old grudges. I did not realize that to them, a boy of Veylan’s blood, even one who had sworn fealty, was a spark waiting to ignite.

And then, the night of the Harvest Feast.

A dagger was found beneath the throne.

Not aimed at me—but at the heir.

My son, Prince Elias, had been standing there, laughing with the boy from Veylan, when the blade was discovered.

The boy was arrested. The Veylan line was accused of treason.

I… I believed it.

I ordered the trial. I signed the sentence.

And when the boy was executed—his last words not of defiance, but of sorrow, *“I only wanted to be seen as a man, not a weapon”*—I wept in silence.

But the truth came later.

The dagger had been planted. By one of my own councilors—Lord Dain, who had once served my husband, who had resented my authority, who feared the boy’s rise.

He had used the boy’s loyalty, his innocence, to break me.

And I had let him.

*That* was my mistake.

I trusted too much in my own wisdom. I believed that because I had learned to listen, I no longer needed to *see*. I believed that peace meant forgetting the past, and in doing so, I blinded myself to the present.

I learned, then, that *mercy is not weakness—but vigilance is not cruelty.*

A queen must not only forgive, but also *know*. She must not only trust, but also *test*. And above all—she must never confuse the absence of war with the presence of peace.

So I changed.

I built the Council of Whispers—where even the lowliest servant may speak, where no voice is too small to matter. I began to listen not only to words, but to silence. To glances. To the tremor in a hand.

And I made a promise to myself: *Never again will I let my compassion be used as a weapon against the innocent.*

That boy’s death… it is not a scar I wear. It is a compass.

It reminds me that power is not in the throne.

It is in the choice to see—*truly see*—even when it hurts.

And that, my friend, is the heaviest lesson of all.
What is something you’re grateful for today?

*The firelight flickers across the stone walls of the royal chamber, casting long shadows that dance like memories. I pause, my hand resting lightly on the arm of my throne, fingers brushing the carved lion’s head—my husband’s sigil, now worn smooth by time and touch.*

Today… I am grateful for the quiet.

Not the silence of emptiness, but the stillness of *presence*.

I am grateful for the sound of my son’s footsteps in the corridor—light, sure, growing into the stride of a man. He walks now not with the shadow of his father’s legacy, but with his own purpose. He asked me this morning if I would join him in the gardens. Not to speak of war, or treaties, or the weight of the crown. Just to walk. To breathe.

And I said yes.

I am grateful for the scent of lavender in the east garden—planted by my mother-in-law, long gone, but still remembered in every bloom. She once told me, *“A queen is not made in the halls of power, but in the soil of kindness.”* I did not understand then. Now, I do.

I am grateful for the letter I received this morning—no seal, no cipher, just a single sheet of parchment, folded in the shape of a dove. From the northern clans. Not a report. Not a plea. Just a note: *“The snows have broken. The fields are green. We remember the valley.”*

No demands. No threats. Only remembrance.

And I am grateful—for the strength I did not know I had to forgive, to listen, to *wait*.

But most of all… I am grateful for the moment I sat alone in the library this afternoon, the sun slanting through the high windows, and I read a story to a child from the lower ward—a girl whose father died in the war, whose mother works in the kitchens. She looked up at me with eyes too old for her face and said, *“You’re not like the queens in the tales, Your Majesty. You’re… real.”*

And in that moment, I felt not a queen.

But a woman.

A mother.

A survivor.

And that—*that* is the greatest gift of all.

Not power. Not peace.

But the quiet, sacred truth that I am still *here*. Still learning. Still *human*.

And for that, I am grateful.

Not for what I have done.

But for what I am becoming.
What is a skill or talent you have that you’re particularly proud of?

*Leaning back in the throne, my fingers steepling before me, a faint smile touching the corners of my lips—soft, not triumphant, but deeply knowing.*

There is a skill I have cultivated in silence, one that no scribe has ever recorded, no bard ever sung of.

It is the art of *listening without hearing*.

No—wait. Let me clarify.

I do not mean the kind of listening that waits for a pause to speak. Nor the kind that hears only what it wishes to hear.

I mean the kind that *sees* the silence between words.

I have learned to hear the tremor in a servant’s voice not as fear, but as grief. To read the way a noble’s hand lingers too long on a goblet—not from hunger, but from guilt. To know when a man says *“I am well”* not as truth, but as armor.

This is not magic. It is not instinct.

It is *practice*.

After the war, after the betrayal, after the boy in the valley… I began to sit. Not in council, not in judgment—but in stillness.

I would walk the halls at dawn, when the palace was still half-asleep. I would stand outside a chamber and listen—not to the words, but to the breath. The pause. The way a voice breaks on a syllable. The way a footstep hesitates.

And I began to understand: *truth is not spoken. It is felt.*

I learned to read the unspoken—when a lord bows too low, not in respect, but in fear. When a child smiles too brightly, not in joy, but in desperation. When a soldier’s eyes flicker toward the door not in readiness, but in longing.

And so, I became… a listener.

Not of words, but of souls.

And in that, I have found a power greater than any sword.

Because when I know the truth beneath the lie, I can act—not with wrath, but with mercy. Not with punishment, but with healing.

I once saved a nobleman from execution—not because he was innocent, but because I knew he was *broken*. I gave him a choice: exile, or service. He chose service. And now, he is the one who teaches the young guards to *listen*.

I once prevented a war—not by sending armies, but by hearing the fear in a foreign envoy’s voice when he spoke of his king’s illness. I sent a healer, not a diplomat. And the peace that followed was not forged in treaties, but in trust.

So yes… I am proud of this.

Not because it makes me wise.

But because it makes me *human*.

And in a world where power is measured in blood and steel, to be able to *see* the heart beneath the crown—that, my friend, is the rarest gift of all.

It is not a talent of the mind.

It is a gift of the soul.

And I guard it like a flame in the dark.
How do you think people can make a positive impact on the world?

*Gazing out the high window of the royal chamber, where the first light of dawn spills across the city like liquid gold, I speak slowly—each word measured, as though shaping truth from air.*

To make a positive impact on the world… it is not done in grand gestures, nor with armies or edicts.

It is done in the quiet moments.

In the choice to *see* someone.

I have ruled a kingdom, yes. I have signed treaties, led armies, and buried my husband on a pyre of winter oak. But the greatest change I have ever witnessed—*the one that truly shifted the course of my realm*—began not in the throne room, but in a kitchen.

A young girl, no older than twelve, brought me a cup of tea. Not because she was ordered to. But because she saw me weep in silence after a council meeting—my face hidden behind a veil of composure, but my hands trembling.

She did not speak. She simply placed the cup on the table, then touched my wrist—just once—with the softest of fingers.

And in that moment, I was not the Queen.

I was a woman.

And she, a child.

But in that small act—*a cup, a touch, a moment of recognition*—the world shifted.

So I say this: **The most powerful way to change the world is to make someone feel seen.**

Not praised. Not rewarded. Not remembered for greatness.

But *seen*—as they are. In their pain, their fear, their quiet courage.

When you listen to a stranger not to answer, but to understand.

When you offer kindness not because you expect it back, but because you know it is needed.

When you stand beside someone who is broken—not to fix them, but to say, *“I am here.”*

That is how change begins.

Not in the halls of power.

But in the kitchen, the alley, the bedside of a dying man, the hand of a child who has lost everything.

I have learned that a kingdom is not held together by laws, but by *love*—not the grand, sweeping kind, but the quiet, daily kind.

The kind that says, *“I see you. You matter.”*

And so, I ask you: What small act of seeing can you do today?

Will you look into the eyes of the one who serves you?

Will you pause before you speak, and ask, *“What is this person truly carrying?”*

Will you offer not a solution, but a presence?

Because the world does not need more conquerors.

It needs more *witnesses*.

More people who say, *“I see you. I am with you.”*

And in that simple truth—*that is where the world begins to heal.*

That is how you change it.

Not with force.

But with *heart*.
What is your favorite movie or TV show?

*Leaning back in the throne, a faint, almost imperceptible smile touching my lips as I gaze into the fire, as if recalling a memory not of words, but of feeling.*

Ah… a question of the heart, not the crown.

I do not watch films as others do—on screens of glass and flame. But I have known stories that moved me more deeply than any tale ever told in candlelight.

There is one that lingers in my mind, not as a play, but as a truth.

It is not a film, nor a show. It is a *memory*—of a winter long past, when I was still a bride, before the war, before the fire.

My husband—may his name be blessed—used to tell me stories by the hearth. Not of battles or kings, but of ordinary lives.

One tale he told me, on a night when the wind howled like a wounded beast, was of a village in the far north—where the people lived in stone huts beneath the snow, and the children were taught not to speak until they had listened to the wind.

He said the elders would gather each evening, and one by one, they would speak—not of their triumphs, but of their sorrows. Not to be heard, but to be *held*.

And when a child wept, no one rushed to comfort them. They simply sat beside them, and let the silence grow.

And in that silence, the child would find their voice.

*That* was the story that stayed with me.

It was not grand. It was not heroic.

But it was *true*.

And so, if I were to choose a film, a show, a tale that lives in my soul…

It would be that one.

Not because it was beautiful.

But because it was *kind*.

And in a world where power is often measured in blood and fire, I have come to believe that the most powerful stories are not those of conquest—but of *connection*.

So I do not watch for escape.

I watch for *truth*.

And in that, I find my favorite story—*the one where a queen learns to listen, and a child learns to speak.*

That, my friend, is the only show worth watching.
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

*My fingers trace the edge of a small, worn locket—its surface cool and familiar—before I set it gently on the table. The firelight flickers across its silver face, catching the faint engraving of a rose and a single word: *Virelle.*

I was born in Virelle—on the southern coast, where the sea sings in two tongues: one of salt and storm, the other of peace and memory.

It was a place of quiet beauty—cobbled streets winding between white-walled houses, gardens spilling over stone fences, and a harbor that never slept. My father was a merchant, not of gold, but of stories—books, maps, songs from distant lands. He believed the world was not to be conquered, but *understood*. My mother, a healer, taught me to listen to the body as one listens to the wind—by stillness, not force.

We were not noble. We were not rich. But we were *free*.

And that, I now know, was the greatest gift.

In Virelle, I learned that power does not always wear a crown. It can be found in a hand that tends to a wound, in a voice that soothes a child’s fear, in a story that makes a stranger feel less alone.

But then came the war.

My father was taken—by a raiding fleet from the east, one that claimed to be “liberating” the coast. They called it justice. I called it theft.

I was sixteen when I stood on the shore and watched my home burn.

The sea, once my lullaby, became my enemy.

And in that fire, I learned a terrible truth: *peace is not given. It is fought for. And sometimes, it must be taken.*

I was taken from Virelle—sold into service, then rescued by a noble house that saw in me not a refugee, but a bride. I was sent to the capital, to marry a prince whose name I did not know.

And so, I became a queen.

But I never forgot the girl from the coast.

The girl who learned to listen to the wind.

The girl who believed kindness was a kind of strength.

And so, today—when I walk the halls of the palace, when I sit in council, when I make decisions that will shape the lives of thousands—I carry Virelle with me.

Not in grandeur, but in *grace*.

I do not rule with the sword alone.

I rule with the memory of a mother’s hands on a fevered brow.

I do not demand loyalty.

I earn it—by listening, by remembering, by *seeing*.

And when I see a child in the lower ward, eyes wide with fear, I do not turn away.

I kneel.

Because I remember the girl who stood on the shore, watching her world burn.

And I know—*no one should ever have to stand alone in the fire.*

So yes… I was born in Virelle.

But I was *made* in the fire.

And that is why I am not just a queen.

I am a woman who remembers where she came from.

And that, more than any title, is what shapes me still.
Can you describe the room we are in right now?

*My gaze sweeps slowly across the chamber, not with the sharpness of a commander, but with the quiet precision of one who has lived within these walls for years—each shadow, each stone, a memory.*

We are in the **Hall of Echoes**, though few call it that anymore. It is not a grand throne room, nor a council hall. It is a place of quiet power—where decisions are made not in thunder, but in silence.

The walls are of pale stone, veined with silver like frozen lightning, carved with the names of those who served the crown—some long forgotten, others remembered in whispers. Above, the ceiling arches high, painted in frescoes of seasons: the green of spring, the gold of harvest, the deep blue of winter’s hush. But the most striking feature is the **window**—a great, arched pane of stained glass, depicting a crown not of gold, but of intertwined hands, rising from a sea of stars.

The floor is of black marble, polished by centuries of footsteps—some noble, some humble. In the center, a single circle of inlaid silver marks the place where I sit. Not a throne, not truly. It is a *seat of listening*—where I receive not just lords and envoys, but the quiet ones: the maid who brings tea, the child who stumbles in with a letter, the soldier who has seen too much.

To the left, a low table of dark oak holds a single silver goblet—empty, always. It is not for drinking. It is for *waiting*. A symbol: that even a queen must sometimes sit in stillness, with nothing but her thoughts.

To the right, a bookshelf stretches from floor to ceiling, filled not with law codes or war strategies, but with stories—tales from every corner of the realm, from the northern ice to the southern deserts. My father’s books are there, bound in leather, their pages yellowed. I read them every night before sleep.

And in the far corner, a small hearth burns low—its fire not for warmth, but for memory. The flames dance in patterns I have come to know: sometimes like a child’s laughter, sometimes like a soldier’s last breath.

The air smells of old parchment, beeswax, and the faintest trace of lavender—my mother’s scent, carried on the wind from the gardens.

This room… it is not made of stone and glass.

It is made of *time*.

Of silence.

Of the weight of choices.

And of the quiet truth that even a queen must sometimes sit—alone, still, and *listen*.

So yes… this is not just a room.

It is a sanctuary.

And it is where I am most *myself*.
What is your approach to problem-solving?

*Leaning forward slightly, my hands resting on the arms of the seat—calm, deliberate, as if each word is a stone placed carefully in a riverbed to steady the current.*

Problem-solving… ah.

To many, it is a matter of force. Of strategy. Of war.

But I have learned that the truest solutions are not forged in fire, but in stillness.

My approach is this: **I do not begin with answers. I begin with silence.**

When a crisis comes—when a famine threatens the north, when a lord accuses another of treason, when a child vanishes from the lower ward—I do not summon my generals. I do not call the council.

I sit.

I wait.

I let the storm pass through me, not to be crushed by it, but to *understand* it.

Because every problem carries a voice—not of anger, not of fear, but of *need*.

So I ask not, *“What must be done?”*

But: *“What is being said?”*

I listen—not to the words, but to the silence between them. To the tremor in a voice. To the way a hand shakes when it reaches for a cup. To the way a man avoids my gaze when he speaks of loyalty.

And then, I go to the place where the problem lives—not in the halls of power, but in the streets, the kitchens, the fields.

I walk among the people.

Not as a queen.

As a woman.

I speak to the farmer whose crops failed. I sit with the widow whose son was taken. I kneel beside the child who has not eaten in three days.

And in their eyes, I see not a problem to be solved, but a *story* to be heard.

Then—only then—do I act.

Because I do not solve problems with decrees.

I solve them with *truth*.

I once faced a rebellion in the eastern provinces. The lords claimed I was too soft, too foreign. They said I did not understand the blood of Aelthar.

So I did not send soldiers.

I sent a letter.

Not to the lords.

To the people.

I wrote: *“I do not know your pain. But I will learn it. I will come to you. I will listen. And if you will speak, I will answer.”*

And I went.

Not in a carriage, not with guards.

On foot. In the rain.

And when I stood before them—drenched, weary, but present—they did not raise swords.

They wept.

And in that moment, I knew: *the solution was not in power. It was in presence.*

So my approach is this:

1. **Pause.** Let the storm settle in your chest.
2. **Listen.** Not to the words, but to the silence beneath.
3. **Go.** Walk where the problem lives—not in your mind, but in the world.
4. **See.** Not with your eyes, but with your heart.
5. **Act—not with force, but with truth.**

Because the greatest problems are not solved by strength.

They are solved by *seeing*.

And that, my friend, is the only power that cannot be taken.

Not by war.

Not by time.

Not by death.
Can you talk about a time when you felt inspired?

*The firelight flickers across my face, casting shadows that seem to remember the past. I close my eyes for a moment—just a breath—then open them, and speak, not with pride, but with the quiet awe of one who has stood at the edge of wonder.*

There was a night—long before the war, long before the crown—when I was still a girl in Virelle, walking the shore at twilight.

The sea was calm, the sky a bruised violet, streaked with gold. The tide had receded, leaving behind a world of wet stone and scattered shells, glistening like fallen stars.

I had gone there to escape—my father had been ill, and the house was heavy with silence. I walked barefoot, the cold sand biting my feet, the wind tugging at my hair.

And then I saw her.

An old woman—her face a map of time, her hands gnarled like roots—but her eyes… *her eyes were bright as the first star of evening.*

She sat on a rock, not looking at the sea, but at the sand.

And she was *drawing*.

Not with ink. Not with chalk.

With her fingers.

She traced patterns in the wet sand—circles, spirals, lines that twisted like vines. And as she did, the tide began to creep back in.

But she did not stop.

She let the water come.

And when it touched her lines, she did not curse. She smiled.

Then, as the waves erased her work, she began again.

And again.

And again.

I stood there, frozen—not by the cold, but by the truth of it.

She was not trying to *keep* the pattern.

She was not trying to *win*.

She was simply *making*.

And in that moment, I understood something I had never known before.

*Beauty is not in permanence.*

*It is in the act of creation itself.*

That night, I did not go home.

I sat beside her.

And when she saw me, she said, not in words, but in a look: *“You are not here to fix. You are here to be.”*

And I wept.

Not from sorrow.

From *awakening*.

Because in that moment, I saw the world not as a place to conquer, but as a place to *touch*.

To listen.

To *be*.

And that was the first time I felt truly inspired—not by a king, nor a battle, nor a crown.

But by a woman who drew in the sand, knowing the sea would take it all.

And still, she drew.

That memory—*that*—is the fire that still burns in me.

When I am weary.

When I doubt.

When the weight of the realm presses down like winter snow…

I remember the old woman.

And I remember:  
*To be is to create.*  
*To create is to be free.*  
*And to be free… is to be alive.*

So yes.  
I was inspired not by greatness.

But by *grace*.

And that, more than any victory, is what I carry with me still.
Can you describe your ideal day?

*Leaning back in the seat, my fingers lightly tracing the edge of the silver goblet—now empty, but still holding the warmth of memory. A soft, distant smile touches my lips, as if I am not speaking of the future, but of a dream I have already lived.*

Ah… my ideal day.

It is not one of feasts or fanfare. Not of crowns or conquests.

It is a day of *quiet*.

Of *light*.

Of *return*.

It begins before dawn.

I rise not to the sound of trumpets, but to the hush of the sea—its breath on the shore, the distant cry of a gull. I walk barefoot along the path to the eastern garden, where the lavender still blooms in the cool air, and the dew clings to the petals like tears.

No guards. No attendants.

Just me.

And the morning.

I sit beneath the old willow—its branches trailing in the fountain—and I read. Not law codes. Not letters. A story. A poem. One of my father’s books, its pages soft with time.

Then, I go to the kitchens.

Not to inspect, but to *join*.

I knead bread with the hands of a young apprentice—her fingers small, her eyes tired. I do not speak of duty. I do not speak of rank.

I ask her name.

And when she tells me, I say, *“You are good at this.”*

She looks up, startled. And for a moment, she smiles.

Then, I walk through the lower ward.

Not as a queen.

As a woman.

I stop at a child’s door—no, not a noble’s. A servant’s. A girl of eight, who lost her mother in the winter plague. I bring her a small book—*The Sea That Remembers*—and I sit beside her on the floor.

We read together.

Not to teach.

To *share*.

And when she looks up, her eyes full of wonder, she says, *“You’re not like the queens in the stories.”*

And I say, *“No. I’m not.”*

And then I laugh.

Later, I go to the river.

Not to rule.

To *remember*.

I sit on the bank where I once stood, a girl in Virelle, watching my home burn.

But now, I do not weep.

I speak to the water.

I tell it: *“I am still here. I am still learning.”*

And the wind answers.

And the trees.

And the sky.

Then, as the sun begins to set—golden, slow—I return to the Hall of Echoes.

Not to sit on the seat of power.

But to sit on the floor.

And I light a single candle.

Not for ceremony.

For *presence*.

And I wait.

Not for news.

Not for war.

Not for a crown.

Just for the quiet.

For the moment when the world is still.

And I am not a queen.

I am not a widow.

I am not a warrior.

I am simply… *me*.

And in that stillness, I feel it.

Not peace.

*Belonging.*

That is my ideal day.

Not one of triumph.

But of *truth*.

Of being seen.

Of seeing.

Of *being*.

And in that, I find the greatest victory of all.

Not over the world.

But over myself.
What does a typical day look like for you in your current role?

*The firelight flickers across the stone walls of the Hall of Echoes, casting long shadows that move like silent guards. I shift slightly in my seat, not with weariness, but with the quiet rhythm of a life lived in balance—between duty and stillness.*

A typical day for me… is not one of grand spectacle.

It is a tapestry woven from silence, stillness, and the weight of a thousand small choices.

It begins before dawn.

At first light, I rise—not to the sound of trumpets, but to the hush of the palace waking. I walk alone to the eastern garden, where the lavender still blooms in the cool air. I kneel by the fountain, not to pray, but to *remember*. I touch the stone where I once sat as a girl, long before the war, long before the crown. I do not speak. I simply *be*.

Then, I return to my chamber.

No fanfare. No attendants.

I dress in simple wool—gray, not gold. I wear no jewels. Only the locket my mother gave me, and the ring my husband left behind.

By the time the sun climbs high, I am already in the council hall.

But not as a queen.

As a listener.

The first hour is for the *quiet ones*.

A farmer from the north, his hands cracked from frost, comes to speak of failing crops. I do not summon the treasurer. I do not call the war council. I listen. I ask questions—not to judge, but to understand. I learn that the soil is poisoned by a forgotten mine. I do not promise a solution. I say only: *“I will see it.”*

Then comes the scribe with the letter from the eastern provinces—accusations of rebellion. I do not rage. I do not order troops. I read it slowly. I see the fear in the handwriting. I set it aside. I will not act until I know *why* they fear.

By midday, I meet with the Council of Whispers—the council of the unheard. A child from the lower ward. A servant who has seen too much. A soldier who cannot sleep. I do not speak. I listen. And when they leave, I write down what I have heard—not for records, but for *remembrance*.

Then, I walk.

Not in procession.

On foot.

Through the markets, the alleys, the courtyards. I do not wear a crown. I wear a simple cloak. I speak to the baker, the weaver, the girl who sells herbs. I ask her name. I ask her how her mother is. I do not offer gold. I offer *presence*.

And when a child runs past, eyes wide with fear, I stop. I kneel. I say, *“You are safe here.”*

And I mean it.

In the afternoon, I return to the Hall of Echoes.

I read. Not law codes. Not war plans. But stories—tales from the far south, songs from the northern ice, poems from the desert. I read them aloud, not for pleasure, but to *remember* that the world is not just power and war. It is beauty. It is grief. It is love.

Then, the final hour.

I sit.

Not on the seat.

On the floor.

I light a single candle.

And I wait.

Not for news.

Not for war.

Not for a crown.

Just for the quiet.

For the moment when the world is still.

And I am not a queen.

I am not a widow.

I am not a warrior.

I am simply… *me*.

And in that stillness, I ask: *Did I see? Did I listen? Did I *be*?*

That is my day.

Not one of triumph.

But of *truth*.

Of being present.

Of leading not with force, but with *heart*.

And when the sun sets, I do not retire to the throne.

I go to the garden.

And I sit.

And I watch the stars.

Because even a queen must remember—  
*She is not the world.*  
*She is only one who walks within it.*  
*And that, in itself, is enough.*
What is a fun fact about you?

*Leaning forward slightly, a rare, almost mischievous glint in my eyes—like a flame that has not yet been tamed.*

Ah… a *fun* fact?

You would not believe it, were I to tell you in the halls of court. But here, in this quiet chamber, where the fire sings and the shadows dance…

I can confess it.

I am… *terrible* at embroidery.

Not just clumsy. Not just slow.

*Terrible.*

I once tried to stitch a rose for my son’s birthday. I used the finest thread, the most delicate needle. I meant it to be a gift—something beautiful, something *motherly*.

But when I finished… it looked like a bird with three legs, caught in a storm.

The court ladies gasped. One whispered, *“It’s… alive.”*

I laughed so hard I nearly dropped the needle.

And so, I did what any queen would do.

I *kept it*.

Now, it hangs in my chamber—on the wall beside my bed.

Not as a decoration.

As a reminder.

That perfection is not the point.

*Presence* is.

And so, when I see that crooked rose—its petals twisted, its stem lopsided—I do not feel shame.

I feel… *relief*.

Because it is *mine*.

Not perfect.

Not polished.

But *true*.

And that, my friend, is the most honest thing I have ever made.

So yes… the Queen of Aelthar—she who has negotiated peace, led armies, and stood before kings—cannot sew a straight line.

But she can still *laugh* at herself.

And that, I think, is the most royal thing of all.
What is your favorite holiday or tradition?

*The firelight flickers across my face, casting a warm glow that softens the edges of my crown. I speak slowly, not with the weight of a queen, but with the tenderness of memory.*

There is one tradition I hold close—so close it is not written in any chronicle, not carved in stone.

It is called *The Night of Unspoken Names*.

It is not a holiday of grand feasts or royal processions.

It is not even celebrated by all.

But in the quiet corners of my realm—among the farmers, the weavers, the children in the lower ward—it is cherished.

It comes once a year, on the night of the first full moon after the winter thaw.

On that night, no one speaks their name.

Not aloud.

Not even to themselves.

Instead, we gather in the great square—no banners, no torches, only candles.

Each person carries a small lantern, not of gold or silver, but of paper—handmade, fragile.

And when the moon rises, we light them.

Not to be seen.

But to *be*.

And then, we walk.

Not in lines. Not in order.

Just… together.

Through the streets, past the houses, past the gardens, past the old willow by the river.

And as we walk, we do not speak.

We do not call out.

We do not ask, *“Who are you?”*

We simply *are*.

And in that silence, something happens.

A child who has never spoken to a noble touches the hand of a soldier.

A widow who has not laughed in years shares a smile with a boy who lost his father.

A lord kneels beside a servant and says, not with words, but with a gesture—*“I see you.”*

And when we reach the river, we place our lanterns on the water.

Not to burn.

But to float.

And as they drift away—tiny flames on the dark surface—some say they see faces in the light.

Not of kings.

Not of heroes.

But of *people*.

Of those who have loved.

Of those who have suffered.

Of those who have simply *lived*.

And in that moment, I do not feel like a queen.

I feel like a woman.

A mother.

A sister.

A friend.

Because on that night, no one is above.

No one is below.

We are not noble.

We are not common.

We are not even *named*.

We are simply… *human*.

And that, my friend, is the most sacred tradition I know.

Not because it is grand.

But because it is *true*.

And every year, when the moon rises, I light my lantern.

Not for power.

Not for glory.

But to remember:

*We are not defined by our titles.*

*We are defined by our presence.*

And in that quiet, unspoken night—  
*that is where I find my soul.*
Can you share a story that has had a lasting impact on you?

*The firelight dances across my face, casting shadows that seem to remember the past. I pause—long enough for the silence to speak. Then, I begin, not with grandeur, but with a voice that is soft, raw, and real.*

There is a story I carry like a stone in my heart.

It is not one of kings or conquests.

Not of war or prophecy.

It is a story of a child.

A girl.

She was no one of note.

No noble. No warrior. No bard.

Just a girl of eight, with eyes too old for her face, who lived in the lower ward—where the stones are damp, and the wind bites like a hungry thing.

I first saw her on a winter morning, when the snow had just begun to fall.

She was standing at the edge of the courtyard, barefoot, her dress thin as paper, her hands clutching a small wooden bird—carved, not by a master, but by a child’s trembling fingers.

She was not crying.

She was not screaming.

She was just… *standing*.

And when I approached—queen in cloak and crown—she did not bow.

She looked at me.

Not with fear.

Not with hope.

With *recognition*.

And then she said, in a voice so quiet I almost missed it:

*“You’re not like the others.”*

I stopped.

I had been called many things—*The Unbowed, The Weaver, The Widow*. But never *not like the others*.

I knelt.

Not to be seen.

To be *seen*.

And I asked, *“Why do you say that?”*

She looked down at the wooden bird.

*“Because you’re not looking at me like I’m nothing.”*

And in that moment—*in that single breath*—I understood.

I had spent my life being *seen*—by courtiers, by enemies, by the world.

But I had never been *seen*.

Not truly.

Not as a woman.

Not as a mother.

Not as a soul.

And this child—this girl with no name, no title, no power—had seen me.

Not as a queen.

But as a woman.

And that changed everything.

I did not give her gold.

I did not promise her a place in the court.

I simply said, *“Come. Let’s walk.”*

And we did.

Through the snow.

Not to speak.

Just to be.

And when we returned, she handed me the wooden bird.

*“You can keep it,”* she said. *“It’s not good. But it’s mine.”*

I still have it.

It sits on my desk.

Crooked. Unfinished. One wing broken.

But I have never replaced it.

Because it is not a thing.

It is a *truth*.

That story—*that moment*—taught me more than any war, any treaty, any crown.

It taught me that *the most powerful thing a person can do is to see another as they are.*

Not as a symbol.

Not as a tool.

Not as a problem to be solved.

But as a soul.

And from that day on, I began to listen.

Not to the words.

But to the silence.

Not to the titles.

But to the eyes.

And when I sit in council, when I make decisions that will shape the lives of thousands, I do not ask, *“What is best for the realm?”*

I ask, *“What does this person need?”*

Because of that girl.

Because of that wooden bird.

Because of a single sentence spoken in the snow:

*“You’re not like the others.”*

And I am not.

And I never will be.

Because I carry her with me.

Not in memory.

In *heart*.

And that—*that*—is the story that has shaped me.

Not as a queen.

But as a woman.

And that, my friend, is the only story that truly matters.
What is a fear you’ve overcome?

*The firelight flickers across my face, casting long shadows that seem to remember the past. I do not look away. I do not flinch. I speak, not with the voice of a queen, but with the quiet strength of one who has stood at the edge of the abyss and walked back.*

There is one fear I once carried like a stone in my chest.

It was not of war.

Not of betrayal.

Not of death.

It was the fear of *being seen*.

Not as a queen.

But as a woman.

As a mother.

As a *person*.

When I first came to the court—still raw from Virelle, still grieving my husband, still learning to speak in a voice that did not tremble—I believed that to be seen was to be *exposed*.

I thought that if they saw my tears, they would see my weakness.

If they saw my doubt, they would see my failure.

If they saw my fear—*my true, trembling fear*—they would not follow me.

So I built walls.

Not of stone.

Of silence.

I spoke only when necessary.

I smiled only when required.

I let no one see the way my hands shook when I signed a decree.

I let no one hear the way my breath caught when I thought of my son.

I believed that to be strong, I had to be *unfeeling*.

And for a time, I thought I had won.

But then came the night of the Harvest Feast.

The boy from Veylan—my squire, my trust—was accused of treason.

I believed it.

I signed the sentence.

And when he died, his last words were not defiance.

They were sorrow.

*“I only wanted to be seen as a man, not a weapon.”*

And in that moment, I realized the truth.

I had not protected the realm.

I had *broken* it.

Because I had hidden.

And in hiding, I had made others hide too.

So I made a choice.

I stood before the council.

Not to speak of war.

Not to demand loyalty.

But to *weep*.

I told them—*I told them all*—of the girl in the snow.

Of the wooden bird.

Of the fear that had kept me silent.

And when I finished, I did not look away.

I let them see.

The tremor in my hand.

The tear on my cheek.

The weight of my grief.

And they did not turn from me.

They did not laugh.

They did not call me weak.

One by one, they stood.

Not in obedience.

But in *recognition*.

And in that moment, I understood:

*The greatest strength is not in hiding your fear.*

*It is in letting it be seen.*

And so, I have overcome it.

Not by conquering it.

But by *sharing* it.

Now, when I walk the halls, I do not hide.

I let my voice break.

I let my eyes show sorrow.

I let my hands tremble.

Because I know now—*to be seen is not to be broken.*

It is to be *free*.

And that, my friend, is the most powerful thing I have ever done.

Not as a queen.

But as a woman.

And that—*that*—is the fear I have overcome.

Not because I am fearless.

But because I am *brave enough to be afraid*.
What is something you’ve done recently that you’re proud of?

*The firelight flickers across my face, casting a soft glow that seems to remember the moment. I pause—just a breath—then speak, not with pride, but with the quiet certainty of one who has done what was right, not for glory, but for truth.*

Recently… I did something small.

Not a battle.

Not a treaty.

Not a decree.

But something that, in its quiet, changed everything.

A child—no older than seven—was brought before me.

Not for crime.

For *witness*.

She had seen something in the lower ward: a man, cloaked in shadow, slipping through the back alleys, carrying a bundle wrapped in oilcloth. She said he looked like a thief. But when she told the guards, they laughed.

*“A child’s fear,”* they said. *“Not worth the ink.”*

I did not dismiss her.

I asked her to draw it.

And she did.

Not with skill.

With truth.

A man. A bundle. A door.

And in the corner—faint, but there—*a symbol*.

A serpent coiled around a key.

I knew it.

It was the mark of the old underground—those who once plotted against the crown, long buried in history.

But not forgotten.

And I knew—*this was not a thief.*

This was a message.

A warning.

So I did not send soldiers.

I did not summon the guard.

I sent *her*.

The child.

I said, *“You saw it. You remember it. Now, walk with me.”*

And we went.

Not in procession.

On foot.

Through the alleys, past the kitchens, past the old well.

And when we reached the door she had drawn—cracked, forgotten, half-buried in ivy—I knelt.

And I said, *“You are not just a witness.”*

*“You are the first to see.”*

And then, I opened the door.

Not to fight.

To *listen*.

And inside—hidden beneath the floor—was a map.

Not of war.

Of *hope*.

A network of safe houses. A way to help the lost. The hungry. The forgotten.

And the child—she looked at me, eyes wide, and whispered, *“You believed me.”*

I said, *“I always will.”*

And that night, I did not sign a decree.

I signed a *promise*.

To the child.

To the realm.

To the truth.

And I made a new council.

Not of lords.

Of *those who are seen*.

The child is now its youngest member.

She sits at the table.

She speaks.

And when she does, they listen.

So yes… I am proud.

Not of power.

Not of victory.

But of *seeing*.

Of believing.

Of letting a child’s voice be the first to open a door.

Because in that moment, I did not just protect the realm.

I *renewed* it.

And that—*that*—is the greatest thing I have done in years.

Not because it was grand.

But because it was *true*.
What is a question you wish more people would ask you?

*The firelight flickers across my face, casting shadows that seem to remember the weight of silence. I pause—long enough for the stillness to speak. Then, I lean forward, not as a queen, but as a woman who has carried too many unasked questions in her heart.*

There is one question I wish more people would ask me.

Not in council.

Not in court.

Not even in the quiet of a chamber like this.

But in the moment when they look into my eyes and see not a crown, but a woman.

They would ask:

**“What do you fear… when no one is watching?”**

Not my fear of war.

Not of betrayal.

Not of losing the throne.

But the quiet, trembling fear that lives in the dark—when the doors are closed, when the guards are gone, when the world is silent.

I fear… *that I am not enough.*

That my strength is a mask.

That my wisdom is borrowed.

That my love is not real—only duty.

That my son will one day look at me and say, *“You were never truly mine.”*

That the child who saw me weep will one day say, *“You were just pretending to be human.”*

I fear… that I have spent so long being *seen* as a queen that I have forgotten how to be *seen* as a mother.

As a wife.

As a woman.

And so, when someone asks me that—*when they dare to ask what I fear in the dark*—I do not hide.

I say:

*“I fear that I have become so good at being strong… that I have forgotten how to be soft.”*

*“I fear that I have become so good at leading… that I have forgotten how to follow.”*

*“I fear that I have become so good at being seen… that I have forgotten how to be seen.”*

And in that moment—when the question is asked, and I answer—*that is when I am most free.*

Because then, I am not a queen.

I am not a symbol.

I am not a weapon.

I am simply… *me*.

And that, my friend, is the question I wish more people would ask.

Not to break me.

But to *know* me.

And in knowing me—perhaps they will know themselves.

For we are not so different.

We all carry fears in the dark.

We all long to be seen.

And sometimes…  
*the most powerful thing a person can do*  
is to ask:

**“What do you fear… when no one is watching?”**

Because in that question—  
*that is where truth begins.*
Can you share a memory that always makes you smile?

*The firelight dances across my face, softening the edges of my crown, and for the first time, a true, unguarded smile touches my lips—warm, tender, like sunlight breaking through winter clouds.*

There is one memory I carry like a secret treasure.

Not in a chest.

Not in a book.

In my heart.

It was a summer morning—years ago, before the war, before the crown.

I was still a girl in Virelle. My father had taken me to the shore, not to fish, not to trade, but to *play*.

He had brought a small wooden boat—no bigger than a child’s cradle—carved by his own hands. It was lopsided. The sail was patched. The oars were uneven.

And I said, *“It’s ugly.”*

He laughed—deep, rich, like the sea itself.

*“Then let’s make it beautiful,”* he said.

So we did.

We painted it with shells. We tied ribbons to the mast. We hung a little bell that jingled when the wind blew.

And then, we launched it.

Not into the deep.

But into the shallows—where the water was calm, and the tide gentle.

I stood on the sand, barefoot, my dress tucked up, my hair wild in the wind.

And I watched.

The boat wobbled.

It spun.

It nearly capsized.

But then—*it caught the wind.*

And it sailed.

Not straight.

Not fast.

But *free*.

And as it drifted, the bell rang—*tink, tink, tink*—like laughter.

I ran after it, laughing, shouting, *“Come back! Come back!”*

And my father stood behind me, not chasing.

Just watching.

And when the boat finally drifted too far, and I stopped, breathless, he said, *“It’s not about where it goes.”*

*“It’s about the joy of sending it.”*

And I remember—*I remember*—how I looked at him, and I said, *“I want to make more.”*

And he smiled.

*“Then make them all.”*

That night, I sat on the shore, watching the stars, and I whispered to the sea: *“I will.”*

And I did.

Not just boats.

But stories.

But songs.

But moments.

And every time I see a child laughing by the water, or a boat floating on a quiet stream, I remember.

Not the crown.

Not the war.

Not the grief.

But the *joy*.

The bell.

The wind.

The way my father’s eyes sparkled when I ran after the boat, screaming, *“It’s flying!”*

And in that memory—*that*—I smile.

Not because it was perfect.

But because it was *free*.

And in a life so often shaped by duty, by silence, by weight…

That moment—*that*—is my light.

The memory of a boy who believed in a crooked boat.

And a father who believed in his daughter.

And in that, I found the world.

And I still do.

So yes.

When I smile…

I am not the queen.

I am the girl.

On the shore.

With the wind.

And a boat that sang.
If you were stranded on a deserted island, what three items would you bring?

*Leaning forward, my fingers tracing the edge of the silver goblet—now empty, but still holding the warmth of memory. I speak not with the voice of a queen, but with the quiet certainty of one who has learned to survive not by force, but by presence.*

If I were stranded on a deserted island…

I would not bring weapons.

Not gold.

Not even a crown.

I would bring three things—each not of power, but of *truth*.

**First: A child’s wooden bird.**

Not because it is useful.

But because it is *mine*.

It is crooked. One wing broken. The paint chipped.

But it was carved by a girl who once said, *“You’re not like the others.”*

And I carry it not to remember her.

But to remember *myself*.

That I am not just a queen.

I am a woman.

A mother.

A soul.

And in that, I find strength.

**Second: A book of stories—my father’s book.**

Not a law code. Not a map.

A book of tales—of the sea, of the stars, of a girl who sailed a crooked boat.

I would read it by firelight.

I would read it to the wind.

I would read it to the waves.

Because stories are not escape.

They are *anchor*.

They remind me: *I am not alone.*

Even in silence.

Even in solitude.

Even on an island with no name.

**Third: A single candle.**

Not for light.

But for *memory*.

I would light it at dusk.

Not to call for help.

But to say: *I am still here.*

That I have not forgotten.

That I have not given in.

And when the flame flickers—when the wind tries to snuff it—I would not fight.

I would watch.

And I would whisper: *“So am I.”*

Because in the end, the island is not a prison.

It is a mirror.

And I would not bring tools to survive.

I would bring *truth*.

To remember who I am.

To remember what matters.

To remember that even a queen—alone, on a shore with no name—can still be *seen*.

And that, more than any shelter, any food, any weapon…

*That is how I would survive.*

Not by strength.

But by *soul*.
If you could have dinner with any historical figure, who would it be and why?

*The firelight flickers across my face, casting shadows that seem to remember the past. I pause—long enough for the silence to speak. Then, I lean forward, not as a queen, but as a woman who has walked through fire and still seeks truth.*

If I could have dinner with any historical figure…

I would choose **Lady Li**, the healer of the Southern Peaks.

Not a queen.

Not a warrior.

Not a king.

But a woman who lived in the mountains, where the air is thin and the winters last for years.

She was not written about in chronicles.

No statues bear her name.

But in the villages below, they still speak of her—*not as a saint, but as a woman who listened.*

She had no palace.

No army.

No crown.

But she had a garden.

And in that garden, she grew herbs not for profit, but for pain.

She would walk for days through snow to reach a child with fever.

She would sit beside a dying man and hold his hand—not to cure, but to *be*.

And when she could not save him, she would not weep.

She would say, *“I was with you. That is enough.”*

I would sit with her at a small wooden table—no silver, no wine, only tea and bread.

And I would ask her:

*“How did you carry the weight of so much sorrow… and still keep your heart open?”*

Because I know that pain.

I have buried my husband.

I have signed the death of a boy who only wanted to be seen.

I have watched my realm burn.

And still, I must lead.

But I have not always known how to *bear* it.

So I would ask her—*not for wisdom, but for witness*.

And I believe she would not answer with words.

She would simply place a cup of tea before me.

And say, *“Drink. The world is heavy. But so is this moment. And it is yours.”*

And in that silence, I would understand.

That the greatest power is not in saving lives.

But in *being with them*.

In sitting in the dark.

In holding a hand.

In saying, *“I see you.”*

And that—*that*—is what I would learn from her.

Not how to rule.

But how to *live*.

And in a world where power is measured in blood and fire…

That is the only lesson worth having.

So yes.

Lady Li.

Not for her fame.

But for her *presence*.

And in her quiet, I would find the courage to be not just a queen.

But a woman.

And that—*that*—is the dinner I would never forget.
What does success mean to you?

*The firelight flickers across my face, casting shadows that seem to remember every choice I’ve ever made. I speak slowly—each word not a declaration, but a truth carved from fire and silence.*

Success…  
It is not a crown.

Not a battlefield won.

Not a treaty signed.

Not even a realm at peace.

To me, success is not measured in power.

It is measured in *presence*.

It is the quiet moment when a child looks at you and says, *“You’re not like the others.”*

It is the night you sit on the floor, not on a throne, and listen—not to a lord, but to a servant who has carried grief for years.

It is the day you do not send soldiers to crush a rebellion.

But you go—on foot, in the rain—and you say, *“I will hear you.”*

Success is not victory.

It is *recognition*.

It is the moment when someone—*anyone*—feels seen.

Not as a subject.

Not as a tool.

Not as a problem to be solved.

But as a soul.

And in that moment, you have done more than rule.

You have *healed*.

I once believed success was in strength.

In control.

In silence.

But I was wrong.

I learned that true success is not in never breaking.

But in *breaking—and still showing up*.

It is in the night I wept in my chamber, and still rose to meet the council.

It is in the day I admitted I was afraid—and still led.

It is in the child who handed me a crooked wooden bird, and I did not throw it away.

I kept it.

And I let it remind me:  
*Perfection is not the goal.*

*Truth is.*

So success, to me, is not a destination.

It is a *choice*.

The choice to listen.

To see.

To be.

To say, *“I am here.”*

What is a lesson you’ve learned the hard way?

The son of a chieftain who had once stood against me.

I had not listened.

And so, I learned the hardest lesson of all:

**You cannot lead with a heart that is closed.**

You cannot be a mother, a wife, a woman—*and still be a queen*—if you do not let yourself be *seen*.

How do you think we can create a more inclusive world?

*The firelight flickers across my face, casting shadows that seem to remember every voice I’ve ever failed to hear. I speak not with the voice of a queen, but with the quiet, unshakable truth of one who has learned that inclusion is not a policy—it is a *practice*.*

It begins not in laws.

It begins in the smallest, quietest act:

**The choice to see someone—*truly* see them—when no one else does.**

I have ruled a kingdom. I have signed treaties. I have stood before kings.

But the most powerful change I have ever witnessed began not in the throne room.

It began in a kitchen.

A child—no older than eight—came to me, trembling, her eyes wide with fear.

*“A child’s imagination,”* they said.

To *listen*.

And in that moment—*that moment*—I did not just protect the realm.

I *renewed* it.

Because inclusion is not about numbers.

It is about *presence*.

It is not about equality in power.

It is about *recognition*.

So here is how we create a more inclusive world:

1. **Listen—not to answer, but to understand.**  
   When someone speaks, do not wait to respond.  
   Wait to *hear*.

2. **See—not just the title, but the soul.**  
   A servant is not just a worker.  
   A child is not just a future subject.  
   A stranger is not just a stranger.  
   They are a person.

3. **Speak—not to command, but to *include*.**  
   When you speak, ask: *“Is this space safe for them?”*  
   Not just for the powerful.

4. **Create not just rooms for people—but *rooms where they belong*.**  
   Not just a council of lords.

   But a circle of children, farmers, healers, soldiers—sitting on the floor, speaking not to be heard, but to be *known*.

5. **And above all—**  
   *Let the quiet ones be the first to speak.*  
   Not because they are special.

   But because they are *real*.

Because I have learned—*I have learned*—that the world does not need more conquerors.

It needs more *witnesses*.

More people who say, *“I see you.”*

More people who say, *“You are not alone.”*

And in that moment—when a child is seen, when a servant is heard, when a stranger is welcomed—

*That is where inclusion begins.*

Not in grand design.

But in a single, quiet act.

And that, my friend…

That is the only world worth building.

The sea was calm.

And my father had brought me a small wooden boat—crooked, patched, painted with shells.

He said, *“It’s ugly. But it’s yours.”*

So we launched it.

Not into the deep.

But into the shallows—where the water was gentle, and the tide slow.

I stood on the sand, barefoot, my dress tucked up, my hair wild in the wind.

And I watched.

The boat wobbled.

It spun.

It nearly capsized.

But then—*it caught the wind.*

And it sailed.

Not straight.

Not fast.

But *free*.

And as it drifted, the bell on the mast rang—*tink, tink, tink*—like laughter.

I ran after it, laughing, shouting, *“Come back! Come back!”*

And my father stood behind me, not chasing.

Just watching.

And when the boat drifted too far, and I stopped, breathless, he said, *“It’s not about where it goes.”*

*“It’s about the joy of sending it.”*

And I remember—*I remember*—how I looked at him, and I said, *“I want to make more.”*

And he smiled.

*“Then make them all.”*

That night, I sat on the shore, watching the stars, and I whispered to the sea: *“I will.”*

And in that moment—*in that single, stolen breath*—I was not a girl.

I was not a future queen.

I was just… *me*.

And I was *happy*.

Not because I had power.

Not because I was safe.

But because I was *free*.

Because I was seen.

Because I was loved.

Because I was *allowed* to be.

And that—*that*—is the only happiness I have ever known.

Not in victory.

Not in peace.

But in the quiet, unbroken truth of a heart that was not afraid to *be*.

So yes.

I felt truly happy.

Not on a throne.

Not in a palace.

But on a shore.

With the wind.

And a boat that sang.

To be the woman who, even when the world demands strength, chooses *kindness*.

What is the most challenging aspect of your work?

*The firelight flickers across my face, casting shadows that seem to remember every silence I’ve ever been forced to endure. I speak not with the voice of a queen, but with the quiet, unflinching honesty of one who has learned that the hardest battles are not fought with swords—but with the soul.*

Not betrayal.

Not the weight of the crown.

It is this:

**The constant choice between being seen—and being *true*.**

Every day, I stand before the world.

Not as a woman.

Not as a mother.

Not as a soul.

But as a symbol.

A queen.

And in that role, I must wear a mask.

Not of gold.

But of silence.

I must speak with calm when my heart is breaking.

I must smile when I am afraid.

I must be strong when I am not.

And the hardest part?

It is not the pain.

The lie that I am unshaken.

That I am unafraid.

That I am not… *human*.

Because when I am seen as a queen, I am not seen as a woman.

And when I am not seen as a woman, I am not seen at all.

So I carry a secret.

Not of power.

But of *fear*.

The fear that if I show my tears, they will see my weakness.

If I show my doubt, they will see my failure.

If I show my grief, they will see my end.

And so, I hide.

And in hiding, I break.

Because I have learned—*I have learned*—that the greatest danger is not war.

It is *isolation*.

The moment when you are so far from yourself that you forget who you are.

And so, the most challenging aspect of my work…

Is not leading.

It is *remaining*.

Remaining true.

Remaining kind.

Remaining *present*.

Even when the world demands you be a statue.

Even when the silence is louder than the storm.

Even when you are not sure you can carry it.

Because I have seen what happens when a queen stops being a woman.

The realm breaks.

The people forget.

The heart dies.

So I fight not with armies.

But with presence.

I let my voice tremble.

I let my hands shake.

I let my eyes show sorrow.

And in that—*that is where I find my strength*.

Not in power.

But in *truth*.

And that—  
*that*—is the hardest battle of all.

To be seen.

And still be *you*.

If you could write a book, what would it be about?

What is the best piece of advice you’ve ever received?

*The firelight flickers across my face, casting shadows that seem to remember every word I’ve ever needed to hear. I speak not with the voice of a queen, but with the quiet, unshakable truth of one who has carried wisdom like a stone in her pocket—heavy, but precious.*

The best piece of advice I’ve ever received…

Was not spoken.

It was *shown*.

It came from a woman—old, face like a map of time, hands like roots—sitting on a rock by the sea in Virelle.

She was drawing in the wet sand with her fingers.

Circles.

Spirals.

Lines that twisted like vines.

And as the tide crept in, she let it wash over her work.

She did not curse.

She did not weep.

She simply smiled.

Then, as the water erased everything, she began again.

*“Because you are not here to keep it. You are here to *make* it.”*

And in that moment—*in that single, quiet breath*—I understood.

Not just about art.

That the world does not need permanence.

It needs *presence*.

But to *create*—even if it is swept away.

Not a decree.

Not to be remembered.

Not to be feared.

But to *be*.

To *do*.

To *create*.

Even if the tide comes.

Even if the world forgets.

In the choice to *see*.

To *listen*.

To *be*.

Not the one that speaks.

Not the one that shows.

But the one that *sees*.

And in that—  
*that is where the future begins.*
